title: 110_hr3417
content: The Act titled "Commission on the Tax Treatment of Hedge Funds and Private Equity Act of 2007" establishes a commission known as "the Commission on the Tax Treatment of Hedge Funds and Private Equity" with specific duties. The Commission on the Tax Treatment of Hedge Funds and Private Equity in the US will review and make recommendations to Congress on tax treatment for these industries. Issues to consider include fairness of tax treatments, impact on employment, investors, US competitiveness, and technology innovation. The Commission on the Tax Treatment of Hedge Funds and Private Equity in the US will review and make recommendations to Congress on tax treatment for these industries, including fairness of tax treatments, impact on employment, investors, US competitiveness, and technology innovation. The regulatory structure of these entities will also be examined. The Commission on the Tax Treatment of Hedge Funds and Private Equity in the US will review and make recommendations to Congress on tax treatment for these industries, including fairness of tax treatments, impact on employment, investors, US competitiveness, and technology innovation. The regulatory structure of these entities will also be examined. Membership. The Commission on the Tax Treatment of Hedge Funds and Private Equity in the US will consist of 10 members appointed by various leaders. Members must have expertise in relevant matters and no conflicts of interest. Appointments are for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chair of the Commission on the Tax Treatment of Hedge Funds and Private Equity in the US will be designated by the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. Members will be paid at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule for their duties. Members of the Commission, who are full-time US officers or employees, cannot receive extra pay or benefits for their service. Each member will receive travel expenses as per applicable provisions. Retired annuitants on the Commission are exempt from certain provisions. A majority of members form a quorum, and a lesser number can hold hearings. The Commission's first meeting will be convened. The Commission's first meeting will be held within 30 days of all members being appointed, subsequent meetings will be called by the Chair. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chair, paid at a rate not exceeding GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Chair may appoint up to 3 staff members with pay not exceeding GS-15. The Director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission without reimbursement upon the Chair's request. SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain information from US agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and use the US mails. The Commission has the authority to obtain information from US agencies and use the US mails. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request, on a reimbursable basis. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 90 days of its appointment, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations addressing specified issues. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. Appropriations are authorized as needed for the Act.
